intro: Peucedanum gummiferum, commonly known as gum plant or wild angelica, is a flowering plant native to regions of the Caucasus and Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots, parsley, and celery, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small white or yellowish flowers. The plant produces a milky sap that is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and antispasmodic properties. It thrives in moist, temperate climates and is often found in woodland or shrubland habitats. Due to its medicinal uses and ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and herbal gardens.
